title: 106_s1228
content: The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 is also known as the "Media Violence Labeling Act". It establishes a system for labeling violent content in audio and visual media products. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 amends the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act to include a policy regarding violence in audio and visual media products. It aims to establish a system for labeling violent content in these products to inform the public about the nature and intensity of depictions of violence. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 aims to establish a system for accurately labeling violent content in audio and visual media products to inform the public about the nature and intensity of depictions of violence, ensuring the appropriateness for minors of various ages. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 aims to establish a system for accurately labeling violent content in audio and visual media products to inform the public about the nature and intensity of depictions of violence, ensuring the appropriateness for minors of various ages. The Act is further amended to include labeling requirements for products containing violent content by minors of various ages. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 focuses on labeling audio and visual media products to inform the public about violent content. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 allows manufacturers to propose a voluntary labeling system for violent content in various media products without antitrust law restrictions. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 permits a voluntary labeling system for violent content in media products, including interactive video games, without antitrust law restrictions. The labeling system must consider the nature, context, and intensity of violence in the product, assessing all depictions of violence comprehensively. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 allows for voluntary labeling of products with a minimum age requirement based on the depiction of violence. Labels must include symbols and written text, be consistent across all products, and be prominently displayed on packaging. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 requires products or services intended to be viewed to display labels before the commencement, in visual and audio form, for at least five seconds. Advertisements must also include labels in accordance with the Act. The Federal Trade Commission may consider proposals for a labeling system from manufacturers and producers within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 requires products or services to display labels before viewing, with the Commission reviewing and issuing a labeling system within 180 days. Manufacturers and producers must submit proposals for the labeling system. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 mandates the Commission to establish a labeling system if proposals are not submitted within the specified time. Regulations must be in place within a year of the Act's enactment. Starting a year after the Act, products like video games, movies, and sound recordings must bear a label to be sold or distributed. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 requires products like video games, movies, and sound recordings to bear a label issued by the Federal Trade Commission specifying appropriate age restrictions for purchasers and consumers. Starting one year after the Act's enactment, it is prohibited to sell these products to individuals below the specified minimum age. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 mandates labeling for interactive video games, movies, and sound recordings by the Federal Trade Commission to specify age restrictions. The Commission has the authority to investigate improper labeling allegations. A new section allows for civil penalties for violations. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 allows for civil penalties for violations. The Media Violence Labeling Act of 1999 allows for civil penalties up to $10,000 for each violation of subsection (e) or (f) of section 4A. Violations of interactive video game, video program, motion picture, or sound recording products are considered separate violations for each day of non-compliance.
